tossups.question: A.C. Graham’s best known work is titled for the “Disputers of” this entity. Less formally organised experts on this entity are called “redheads,” as opposed to “blackheads” organized under the Celestial Master. Altars to this entity are presided over by the “Three Pure Ones,” (*) who correspond to aspects of this entity’s “internal alchemy.” The original 81-chapter text about this concept exalts a “Mysterious Female” and contrasts this entity with a version that can be named, and is thus not eternal. For 10 points, name this Laozi-formulated “Way.”
tossups.answer: the Dao [or Tao, accept “the Way” until it is read] <EJW>

tossups.question: Princeton’s David MacMillan has led the design of reactors for carrying out redox reactions under these conditions. Electrocyclic ring-opening of cyclo•butenes under these conditions occurs in a disrotatory fashion. Stern-Volmer plots can be used to investigate kinetics of reactions under these conditions. Thermally allowed reactions are contrasted with reactions that require this stimulus, such as the production of vitamin D in humans. Symbolised in reaction schemes as “hv”, for 10 points, name this stimulus necessary for photochemical reactions.
tossups.answer: light [accept UV light or visible light or electromagnetic radiation or sunlight or photochemical] <EM>

tossups.question: The computer program Archaeopteryx is used to view and analyse these constructs. The Fitch and Wagner methods can be used to quantify parsimony when constructing these things. Defining an out-group “roots” these constructs. (*) Molecular clocks are used to provide approximate timescales to these constructs. Each node on these diagrams is called a taxonomic unit. For 10 points, name these branching diagrams which depict evolutionary relationships between clades.
tossups.answer: Phylogenetic Trees [or evolutionary trees or I suppose trees of life]

tossups.question: Key philosophical reference works on this concept include ones by Alan Soble and Irving Singer. Theories of this concept often encounter the fungibility problem. Robert Nozick argued that this concept entails creating a “joint pool” with its object, and thus opposes the “robust (*) concern” view of it with a “union view.” Martha Nussbaum argues that Alcibiades’ drunk speech on this concept “redeems” a Socratic dialogue on it in which Aristophanes claims that humans once had round double-bodies. For 10 points, the Symposium discusses what concept?
tossups.answer: love [also accept sex or sexual desire until “joint pool” and prompt thereafter; prompt on friendship or desire; anti-prompt on any wiseguy who gives any of eros, storge, philia, or agape] <JG>

tossups.question: This musician's version of Embraceable You is the only standard on any of his Atlantic studio albums. The track titles on another of his albums represent works by Sigmund Freud. Another of this musician's albums features his quartet playing into the left stereo channel, while another quartet led by Eric (*) Dolphy plays into the right. He’s not Charlie Parker, but this musician played a plastic saxophone for some recordings, while his frequent collaborator Don Cherry often played a pocket trumpet. For 10 points, name this free jazz saxophonist behind the albums Change of the Century, Something Else!!!! and The Shape of Jazz to Come.
tossups.answer: Ornette Coleman <HO>

tossups.question: A photomontage cover featuring a tyre and a toothbrush is the only known work in this category by John Heartfield. 1,042 works in this category by another artist include a watercolour amaryllis and a 9-panelled Life of Christ. Olaf Peters recreated an exhibition of works in this category and (*) used empty frames to symbolise paintings with this label that were destroyed in a bonfire, like War Cripples by Otto Dix. Emil Nolde was banned from painting when his work received this label. For 10 points, give this term used by the Nazis to condemn modernist art.
tossups.answer: Degenerate Art [or Entartete Kunst] <LC>

tossups.question: A “negative” form of this process in metal oxides is explained in terms of low-frequency rigid unit modes. One formulation of the Gruneisen parameter states that it is proportional to the adiabatic bulk modulus and to a coefficient describing this process. (*) Invar alloy barely undergoes this process, while two materials which undergo it at different rates are used in bimetallic strips. Caused by an increase in average interatomic spacing at higher vibrational energies, for 10 points name this process where things get bigger as they get hot.
tossups.answer: Thermal Expansion (accept descriptive answers like things get bigger when they get hot before the FTP)

tossups.question: This man designed his own eudiometer to measure the goodness of gases for breathing, and he showed that the electric charge of a sphere was largely confined to its surface. This man employed a torsion balance in a series of experiments carried out on (*) Clapham Common to find the density of the Earth. Antoine Lavoisier reproduced this man’s discovery of a gas which gave water when burned in air: hydrogen. For 10 points, name this reclusive natural philosopher, a relative of whom endowed the physics laboratory at the University of Cambridge.
tossups.answer: Henry Cavendish <HO>

tossups.question: In a dream about this group, a flock of geese pick grain before having their necks broken by an eagle. Another two eagles fly into the middle of a debate involving this group and portentously tear into each other. Melantho and Melanthius aided this group, the leader of which (*) is killed after a man shoots an arrow through the rings of twelve axes. For over three years, a woman nightly unravelled a shroud for Laertes to delay this group. For 10 points, name this group of xenia-violating scum that sought Penelope’s hand in the Odyssey.
tossups.answer: The Suitors of Penelope [accept Proci or obvious equivalents] <LC>

tossups.question: One person from this family was referred to as “My English Mare” by Francis I of France. One member was the first woman to be created an hereditary peer upon being made Marquess of Pembroke. That member of this family introduced her husband to (*) Simon Fish’s anticlerical tract A Supplication for the Beggars. The confession of the musician Mark Smeaton led to the conviction of that woman, who was also accused of incest with her brother George. For 10 points, name this family, whose members included the second wife of Henry VIII.
tossups.answer: Boleyn <JS>

tossups.question: The music video for ‘Calling Elvis’ by Dire Straits featured examples of this technique, which was parodied in a 2004 live-action film. This technique made walking unconvincing, so used mechanical transportations such as the hovercraft in Fireball XL5. Characters’ heads contained solenoids to create (*) facial movements, and the only non-speaking model of this type was the water-breathing Marina in Stingray. A 2014 documentary about this animation technique was hosted by Parker and Lady Penelope. For 10 points, name this style of puppet animation pioneered by Gerry and Sylvia Anderson for series such as Captain Scarlet and Thunderbirds.
tossups.answer: Supermarionation [accept marionette animation, or marionettes; prompt on puppetry, or puppets] <LC>

tossups.question: Tim Selwyn was convicted of “sedition” for throwing an axe through a holder of this position’s window. John A. Lee attacked a beloved, cancer-stricken holder of this office as “mentally sick” during a feud with Walter Nash, a future holder who issued the unpopular 1958 “Black Budget.” (*) As holders of this position, Michael Savage devised his country’s “cradle-to-grave” welfare state, and David Lange cemented its anti-nuclear stance. Other holders include Robert Muldoon and Helen Clark. For 10 points, name this position, currently held by Jacinda Ardern.
tossups.answer: Prime Minister of New Zealand [ do not accept or prompt on “Premier of New Zealand,” as that title ceased to exist before any of the clues mentioned] <JG>

tossups.question: This organisation acquired Russell and LCH under the leadership of Xavier Rolet, though an attempted merger with Deutsche Borse fell through. This institution relocated from Threadneedle Street to Paternoster Square in 2004. This institution ceased its practice of “open-outcry” in the wake of the (*) Big Bang deregulations of 1986, which went on to see this institution’s role as a listing authority taken over by the FSA. The FTSE 100 Index tracks the leading 100 companies on, for 10 points, what stock exchange?
tossups.answer: The London Stock Exchange (accept LSE or London Stock Exchange Group)

tossups.question: Towns in this place include Escrow, Hunghung, and Bonk [be-yonk] whilst events that have occurred here include the execution of Lorenzo the Kind and the Borogravian-Zlobenian War. Another event in this place, at Bad Blintz, involved a group of unusual rats and a stupid-looking kid (*) with a pipe. In this place, the compass directions are “turnwise, widdershins, rimwards, and hubwards”, the latter referring to the central spire of Cori Celesti [korry selesti]. Stories set in this place include the characters Nanny Ogg, the Wee Free Men, and Rincewind. For 10 points, name this “flat-earth” carried on four elephants, created by Terry Pratchett.
tossups.answer: Discworld <CB>

tossups.question: Pietro Alfieri detailed the original ornaments of this piece, whose score was first published by Charles Burney. Modern performances of this piece usually follow the 19th century version of W. S. Rockstro, despite the fact he had accidentally transposed part of it a (*) perfect fourth up. Composed for the Tenebrae Service, this work for two choirs features a difficult top C, and performances of it were initially only permitted in the Sistine Chapel on Good Friday. Famously transcribed from memory by a 14-year-old Mozart - for 10 points, name this setting of Psalm 51 by Gregorio Allegri.
tossups.answer: Miserere mei, Deus <Tom>

tossups.question: Submarine groundwater discharge through springs known as vrulja [ver-oo-lee-ah] is responsible for 20% of the inflow into this body of water. In winter, this body of water is subject to the jugo [yoo-go] and bora winds, the latter of which can cause sea ice to form in this body of water’s northern parts; and the coast of this body of water includes the port of (*) Neum [nay-oom], the only access to the sea for one country. The southern limit of this body of water are the Straits of Otranto, which lead into the Ionian Sea. For 10 points, name this sea of the Mediterranean that divides Italy from the Balkans.
tossups.answer: The Adriatic Sea <SC>

tossups.question: One adaptation of this play sees its title character tell a woman to “get up earlier if you want to see a world without colour”, and quarrel over the dog Puff. A guard in this play claims that “there is nothing so comfortable as your own skin” after he sees this play’s protagonist pouring wine (*) on the ground during a dust storm. In both this play and Jean Anouilh’s adaptation, Haemon stabs himself after seeing his betrothed hanging in a cave. This play is set in motion when Ismene's sister defies Creon by performing burial rites for Polyneices. For 10 points, name this Greek tragedy about the daughter of Oedipus.
tossups.answer: Antigone <EJW>

tossups.question: After it survived one of these events, the German cruiser Prinz Eugen was towed to Kwajalein, where she capsized and sank. The Vela incident is often theorised to have been one of these events. In geology, the term “before present” sets the present as 1 January 1950 owing to the changes in the (*) atmosphere caused by these events. The fastest man-made object ever may have been a steel manhole cover that was accelerated by one of these events. For 10 points, name these events carried out at Enewetak and Bikini Atoll.
tossups.answer: Nuclear tests [accept anything to do with a nuclear explosion] <EM>

tossups.question: This author considered how “to disappear” had become a transitive verb in Spanish in an account of her 1982 trip to El Salvador. BZ’s suicide leads Carter’s ex-wife Maria to be institutionalised in a novel by this author, who wrote a 2011 memoir about the death of her daughter Quintana Roo, (*) Blue Nights. In one essay, this author describes meeting drug-dealer Deadeye on Haight Street in San Francisco, while another of her essays opens with the line “we tell ourselves stories in order to live”. For 10 points, name this American author of The White Album and Slouching Towards Bethlehem.
tossups.answer: Joan Didion <EJW>

tossups.question: Commander George Hopkinson organised a disastrous glider invasion of this region, in which less than 10% of the gliders landed within it., Horace West shot 37 prisoners of war in the Biscari massacre in this region. and the Battleaxe Division stormed a hill town in it with intense street fighting in the Battle of (*) Centuripe [Chen-tur-ree-pay]. The body of Glyndwr Michael was used to convince Nazi Germany that this island was not the target of an invasion in Operation Mincemeat. Invaded in Operation Husky, for 10 points, name this island whose Allied invasion ended with the capture of Messina.
tossups.answer: Sicily [prompt on stuff like Italy or the Mediterranean, accept specific parts of Sicily] <JK>

tossups.question: Horizontal gene transfer from bacteria is thought to have given rise to the Ascidians’ ability to bio•synthesise this compound. A carboxy•methyl-substituted derivative of this compound is commonly used as a cation exchange resin. An (*) acetate derivative of this compound is the most common material for dialysis tubing, and Southern blots are often transferred onto a membrane of this substance’s nitro- derivative. This substance comprises multiple linked beta-glucose subunits. For 10 points, name this polysaccharide which makes up plant cell walls.
tossups.answer: Cellulose <EM>

tossups.question: In one work, two characters with this profession bicker after “rancke Winters rage” is bemoaned by Cuddie to Thenot. Mantuanus inspired that work titled for this profession, which includes a dedicatory epistle by E.K. A “reply” to one of these people rejects “thy belt of straw and ivy buds”, and was written by (*) Walter Raleigh. In another poem, a man with this profession describes how “we will sit upon the rocks” and asks “come live with me and be my love”. For 10 points, name this profession titling a “Calendar” by Spenser and whose “passionate” type titles a Marlowe poem.
tossups.answer: Shepherd [accept reasonable synonyms] <JK>

tossups.question: Bukayr ibn Māhān is sometimes called the “father” of this event for leading a shadowy group known simply as “the Da‘wah.” In its aftermath, this event was opposed by a sexually libertine rebel called “The Veiled One” or al-Muqanna‘, who revered this event’s early leader, Abū Muslim. This event (*) ostensibly aimed to restore the “Hashimites” to power and crowned al-Saffāḥ, and a surviving enemy of it founded a caliphate in Cordoba. For 10 points, name this event in which the dynasty of Hārūn al-Rashīd came to power and overthrew the Umayyads.
tossups.answer: the ʿAbbāsid Revolution [accept any answer that gets across the ʿAbbasids/ʿAbbāsiyyūn taking power; accept overthrowing the Umayyads until mentioned] <JG>

tossups.question: This thinker dreamt of the roof of Basel Cathedral collapsing under God's faeces, and commended Pius XII for the dogma of the Assumption of Mary. Sonu Shamdasani is working on publishing this thinker's seven "Black Books." This proponent of "active imagination" and author of (*) Memories, Dreams, Reflections held that individuation involves breaking down one's "persona." The Myers-Briggs test draws on this thinker’s idea of unconscious archetypes. For 10 points, name this Swiss psychologist who postulated the collective unconscious.
tossups.answer: Carl Gustav Jung <LC> Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: Non-fat dry milk or BSA are common blocking agents in this procedure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this technique where proteins are separated by gel electrophoresis then transferred onto a PVDF membrane.
The Western blot is commonly used in the diagnosis of infection by this retrovirus which causes AIDS.

In-cell Western blots combine the features of Western blotting and this technique, where an antibody to the target of interest is bound to a solid surface, mixed with a sample, then probed with a second, labelled antibody.

bonuses.leadin: Only a few women in history have been afforded the privilege of a burial in St Peter’s Basilica. Name some of them, for 10 points each:
answer: St. Petronilla <Tom> [Note to moderator the “ð” symbol makes a sound like the “th” sound in “the”]
parts: This “Minerva of the North” spent much of her later life in Rome, after converting to Catholicism and giving up the Swedish throne. This daughter of Gustavus Adolphus eschewed conventional gender standards, and refused to marry.

In the Investiture Controversy, Henry IV walked barefoot through the snow to the castle of a “Gran Contessa” of this name buried in St. Peter’s. A female claimant of this name opposed Stephen of Blois in the Anarchy.
The relics of this early Christian martyr, sometimes considered to be the daughter of St Peter, occupy a namesake altar in the modern basilica. Her burial is depicted in an altarpiece by Guercino.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each answer some questions about Norse gods and their weapons:
answer: an extra-thick shoe [accept obvious equivalents like boots] <SR>
parts: Brokkr and Eitri forged this hammer following a bet that they could never succeed in making items more beautiful than those of the Sons of Ivaldi, the makers of Sif’s hair and Odin’s spear, Gungnir.

This god had a spectacular sword that fights on its own, but he gave it to his servant Skirnir to woo the giantess Gerðr. In the meantime, he fights with an antler and has a foldable ship called Skiðblaðnir.
The Gylfaginning describes Odin’s silent son Viðarr as obsessively collecting materials to build one of these objects specifically designed to defeat Fenrir.

bonuses.leadin: He wrote a theme in open fifths so that beginner violinists, who could only play four notes, could have the tune. For 10 points each:
answer: Simple Symphony [accept Op. 4 by Benjamin Britten] <RF>
parts: Name this composer of a Concerto Grosso for school string orchestra, also known for a Fantasia on Greensleeves.

This friend of Vaughan Williams included his own arrangement of Greensleeves in the movement ‘Fantasia on the Dargason’ from his second Suite in F for Military Band. He later arranged that movement in a suite written for a girls’ school string orchestra.

This Britten composition for string orchestra includes movements called “Boisterous Bourree” and “Playful Pizzicato”. It quotes familiar themes from the composer's childhood, including Barwick Green, which became the theme for The Archers.

bonuses.leadin: Junya Ishigami designed a very thin one of these buildings for a valley in China, and a destroyed one of these buildings nicknamed “The Hollow Tooth” is located in Breitscheidplatz in Berlin. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this generic type of building, made up of parts such as the nave, the sanctuary, and the vestry.

This architect designed “The Church of the Light” in Ibaraki, which uses scaffolding planks for pews and receives natural light from a cross-shaped slit on the back wall. He also designed the Pulitzer Art Foundation and the museum 21_21 Design Sight.
Another iconic church, the crown-shaped cathedral of Brasília, was designed by this man, the chief architect of the city. This man also designed the United Nations headquarters in New York.

bonuses.leadin: A Cambridge lecture about this play was criticized in The Daily Mail under the headline “Alas, poor Snowflakes!” For 10 points each:
answer: trigger warnings [accept content warnings, content notes]
parts: Name this play, in which Lavinia holds a stick in her mouth to write out the names of her rapists Chiron and Demetrius.

In The Guardian, Ian Burrows defended his use of these tools in that lecture on sexual assault in drama. These tools are intended to alert students to discussions which might be difficult for trauma victims.

Ian Burrows compared Titus Andronicus to this Sarah Kane play about the relationship between a young woman and a tabloid journalist in a war-torn Leeds. The Daily Mail described it as “a disgusting feast of filth.”

bonuses.leadin: This character’s mother successfully executes a scheme to have her catch a cold and be forced to stay at Netherfield. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this kind, intelligent and all-round lovely character, who falls for Caroline’s brother Charles at a party at Meryton. She finally marries him after sorting out her little sister’s problem with George Wickham.
Jane Bennet is the elder sister of Elizabeth Bennet, who eventually gets together with the curmudgeonly Mr Darcy in this romantic Regency novel.

Another character that Austen just happened to give her name to was the beautiful and talented Jane Fairfax from Emma, an orphan who was taken in and given an impressive education by this man and his wife.

bonuses.leadin: This graph was supposedly sketched on a napkin by its namesake during a meeting with Dick Cheney in 1974. For 10 points:
answer: capital income tax [prompt on corporate or corporation tax] <KV>
parts: Name this inverted-U shaped graph, which depicts the theoretical relationship between tax rates and tax revenue, showing that if tax rates are too high, cutting tax rates may increase tax revenue.
These taxes named for a Cambridge economist increase efficiency by correcting for the over-consumption of a taxed good causing a negative externality.

A result by Chamley and Judd states that this type of tax’s optimal rate is zero in a steady state, though Straub and Werning showed that a positive rate may be optimal when the tax’s income effect is taken into account.

bonuses.leadin: Many songs from this country, such as Dharma’s ‘Plastic Doll’, Klein and MBO’s ‘Dirty Talk’ and ‘Lectric Workers’ ‘Robot is Systematic’, were promoted by the label ZYX as part of its namesake ‘disco’ genre. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, whose other ‘80s music stars included Black Box and Adriano Celentano.
This Italian producer pioneered Italo disco with works like ‘Chase’. He composed both ‘Flashdance’ and ‘Take My Breath Away’, and collaborated with Phil Oakey on ‘Together in Electric Dreams’.
Often inspired by Italo disco, this Italian DJ, who died in 2017, is best known for the seminal 1995 instrumental track ‘Children’.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the many achievements of Robert Woodward. For 10 points each:
parts: With Geoffrey Wilkinson, Woodward was the first to propose the correct structure for this organometallic compound, which has now largely superseded tetraethyl lead as an anti-knock agent in petrol.
Woodward proposed the first total synthesis of this antimalarial drug which is derived from the bark of the cinchona tree and gives tonic water its bitter taste.

The Woodward-Hoffmann rules describe the mechanisms of pericyclic reactions in a way similar to this Japanese chemist’s frontier molecular orbital theory. This chemist shared the Nobel prize with Hoffman after Woodward’s death.

bonuses.leadin: We’ll soon be getting a fifth season of the Bluths, but until then, answer the following on what the stars of Arrested Development are up to right now. For 10 points each:
parts: As well as delusional magician GOB (joab), Will Arnett has won acclaim for playing the title role in this animated Netflix comedy about a depressed, washed-up TV sitcom actor who just happens to be a horse.

Jessica Walter similarly moved into animation, and was drawn to Archer due to the similarities between Lucille and Malory. This actor voices her screen son Sterling Archer, and also voices Bob on Bob’s Burgers.

Alia Shawkat, meanwhile, has starred in this “millennial noir” series about Dory Sief, who obsesses over the disappearance of her college acquaintance Chantal with her friends Drew, Elliott and Portia.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some authors who created fictional Cambridge colleges:
answer: Kingsley Amis [prompt on Amis, do not accept “Martin Amis”]
parts: All Saints' College, modelled on the other place's All Souls' College, features in this man’s novel The Green Man, in which an innkeeper is haunted by Thomas Underhill, a one-time fellow of the college.
Skullion is a head porter who contrives to become Master of the fictional college of Porterhouse in the novel Porterhouse Blue, by this author of Wilt and Riotous Assembly.

Fellows at a fictional college created by this author include Roy Calvert, a scholar of Sogdian Manichaeism. The unnamed college is geographically similar to Christ's, where this author completed a PhD in physics.

bonuses.leadin: In this story, it is said that a child’s inherited warrior spirit allows him to ford a river in a forest, but that warrior’s spirit fails him, causing him to run away from a rabbit and get lost. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this story, in which a child follows retreating soldiers in the American Civil War, ultimately leading him to his family’s farm which has caught fire, which he didn’t notice because the child was deaf-mute.
This story by the author of “Chickamauga” sees Peyton Farquhar hallucinate his escape from being hanged, after he tampered with the railway of the title structure during the Civil War.
“Chickamauga” and “An Occurrence At Owl Creek Bridge” were written by this American satirist, known for writing about a chess-playing robot in Moxon’s Master and for writing The Devil’s Dictionary.

bonuses.leadin: After becoming paralysed while fighting in the Boer War, this man was miraculously entirely cured during a bobsled crash at St Moritz. For 10 points each:
answer: Viscount Rothermere [or Harold Harmsworth; prompt on Harmsworth]
parts: Name this early advocate of strategic bombing, whose efforts as Chief of the Air Staff over the 1920s gave rise to his nickname, the Father of the Royal Air Force.

As Air Minister, this man wore Trenchard down over several days in order to get him to first accept the role of Chief of the Air Staff. This magnate founded the Daily Mail with his brother Viscount Northcliffe.

Returning as Chief of the Air Staff in 1919, Trenchard served under this man, at the time the Secretary of State for Air. After crossing the floor, he served as Chancellor in the 1920s, before his most famous role during WWII.

bonuses.leadin: The conclusion of one of this poet’s poems asks “Creatures of a day! What is anyone? / What is anyone not?”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Ancient Greek lyric poet, best known for celebrating athletic prowess in his Olympian and Isthmian victory odes. He stated “I deplore the lot of tyrants” in a poem concerning Hieron of Syracuse.
Pindar’s eighth Olympian ode includes a lengthy digression about the construction of walls in this city, which is the principal setting of the war described in the Iliad.

This other Greek lyric poet, whose works are mostly known from a single papyrus discovered in 1896, is often considered a rival of Pindar. His third victory ode also celebrates Hieron’s chariot ability at the games.

bonuses.leadin: Karl Popper took the term “open society” from this thinker’s work The Two Sources of Morality and Religion, and this thinker reflected on Einstein’s theory of relativity in Duration and Simultaneity. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French author of Matter and Memory, who argued that laughter has a primarily moral and social function in essays “on the meaning of the comic” and who formulated the idea of élan vital in Creative Evolution.

Bergson’s doctoral thesis is titled in English for Time and this concept, which Bergson rooted in experiencing “duration.” Galen Strawson’s “basic argument” posits the impossibility of this ability to make meaningful choices.

Central to Bergson’s thought is his privileging of this faculty, which he contrasts with “analysis” and holds to be superior to Kantian rationalism in that it allows one to “enter into” absolute knowledge.

bonuses.leadin: One of these constructs can be differentiated with respect to another using the Radon-Nikodym derivative. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these countably additive set functions. Lebesgue names one of these functions which takes value b-a on the real interval [a,b].

A Radon-Nikodym derivative of a Lebesgue measure can be used to define a probability density function, which specifies the continuous type of this object. Examples of these constructs include the binomial, Poisson and Gaussian.

Measure theory lets you interpret this generalised function as the probability density function of a distribution which takes value 0 with probability 1. This function is 0 for all inputs except zero, and has integral 1.

bonuses.leadin: This object is typically used in conjunction with a device called a “mogen-shield” and is sometimes placed under the pillow of those undergoing the ritual in which it is used. For 10 points each:
answer: the Izmel [or knife used for brit milah/bris; or knife used for circumcision; do not accept or prompt on any other type of cutting implement]
parts: Name this object used by a mohel in a certain Jewish ritual, which according to Halakhah must allow for dam brit. A description is acceptable.
The Izmel is a tool employed to amputate this body part from male children during a Jewish ceremony carried out on the eighth day of a child's life.

Following the circumcision, Orthodox mohels perform this ritual of sucking blood from the child’s wound. The “b’peh” version of this ritual, which uses the mohel’s mouth, has been linked to cases of infant herpes.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about Dutch Golden Age landscape painting:
answer: Jacob Isaackszoon van Ruisdael [do not accept Jacob Salomonszoon van Ruysdael - he’s a different painter - but just Ruisdael is fine]
Claude Lorrain [accept either underlined portion or simply Le Lorrain; also accept Claude Gellée] <JK>
parts: This artist of the Dutch Golden Age produced several landscape etchings and the painting Landscape with the Good Samaritan, but is better known for his numerous self-portraits and The Anatomy Lesson of Dr Nicolaes Tulp.

This teacher of Meindert Hobbema was perhaps the pre-eminent Golden Age landscape artist. His works include The Windmill of Wijk bij Duurstede [wike-buy-DOOR-steh-duh], The Jewish Cemetery, and several views of his hometown, Haarlem.

Jan Both introduced the ideas of Italianate landscape painting to the Netherlands after working with this French painter. His pioneering seascapes include Embarkation of the Queen of Sheba and Seaport at Sunset.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about elasticity:
parts: For elastic materials, Young’s modulus is the ratio of stress to this quantity. It is equal to the extension of the sample over its length.

This quantity and Young's modulus completely specifies the properties of a linear, homogeneous and isotropic elastic medium. This quantity is the ratio between strains in orthogonal and parallel directions to applied stress.

This physical system consists of a thin elastic beam pivoted at one or both ends loaded axially. The beam remains unbuckled until a critical load as the boundary conditions of the thin elastic beam means deflection can only occur for quantised values of applied load.

bonuses.leadin: For much of his time in office, this Prime Minister was compelled to negotiate with Henry Grattan in order to enact his legislation in Ireland. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this long-serving Prime Minister, who resigned in 1801 in the face of George III's opposition to his proposals for Catholic relief in Ireland, which this Prime Minister hoped to carry out alongside the Act of Union.

Pitt the Younger's decision to unite British and Irish parliaments was in part spurred by a 1798 rebellion in Ireland by the United Irishmen, an organisation led and co-founded by this revolutionary nationalist.

This Irish historian examined Wolfe Tone’s part in the rising in a 1998 biography. His other works include The Rise and Fall of the Irish Nation: the Catholic Question, 1690-1830 and the one-volume Ireland: A History.

bonuses.leadin: Like many of the big European empires, the Spanish Empire isn’t quite dead. For 10 points each:
parts: This city on the coast of Morocco, along with Ceuta [thé-oo-ta], is an autonomous city of Spain, and was a free port before Spain joined the EU.

This small Spanish-controlled island, lying nearly midway between southern Spain and northern Africa, and home to a small Spanish naval garrison, gives its name to the westernmost portion of the Mediterranean.
One part of its empire that Spain would very much like back is this promontory of southern Spain with its namesake Rock, currently a British possession, but who knows what will happen post-Brexit...?

bonuses.leadin: One form of capital punishment in Rome was the Damnatio ad bestias, which involved throwing people to the lions. For 10 points each:
answer: Parricide [Accept word forms of killing parent, prompt on killing a relative]
parts: Later writers likely exaggerated the number of these people executed ad bestias, though Tacitus records that Nero ordered these people to be killed by dogs after the Great Fire of Rome.
This crime, a kind of murder, was punished by Romans by being sewn up into a sack with a cockerel, a dog, a monkey, and a viper, and then being thrown into a river.
Crucifixion was a quite common Roman punishment. For example, after Spartacus’ rebellion, Crassus lined this location with over 6,000 crucified slaves.

bonuses.leadin: If you don’t get these bonuses right, you can always claim that you’re operating on a system of “alternative facts”. For 10 points each:
answer: opioid overdose epidemic [prompt on drugs by asking “what kind?”]
parts: “Alternative facts” is a phrase popularised by this US politico, who was Donald Trump’s campaign manager. Several news shows will no longer book this woman due to her fabricating events like the “Bowling Green Massacre”.

In November 2017, Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced Conway’s appointment to oversee the response to this US crisis. Obama’s 21st Century Cures Act allocated over $1bn to combatting this growing problem.
The commission investigating the crisis had previously been led by this man, who gained notoriety for his role in the Fort Lee lane closure scandal as Governor of his home state.
